name: Solomon's Porch (Stoa of Solomon)
shortDescription: The eastern colonnade of the Jerusalem Temple where Jesus taught during the Feast of Dedication (John 10:23) and where Peter preached his sermon identifying Jesus as the Prophet Moses foretold (Acts 3:11-26). It became the regular gathering place of the early Church (Acts 5:12).
description: Solomon's Porch (Greek: stoa tou Solomontos) was a magnificent covered colonnade running along the eastern side of the Temple Mount in Jerusalem. According to tradition, it was built on the site of Solomon's original Temple construction, incorporating ancient stones. This portico served as a place of teaching and gathering, where Jesus Himself taught during the Feast of Dedication (John 10:23). After Pentecost, it became the primary gathering place of the early Church, where the apostles performed signs and wonders and Peter preached his powerful sermon connecting Jesus to the prophecy of Moses and the covenant of Abraham (Acts 3:11-26).
longDescription:
Solomon's Porch (also called the Stoa of Solomon or the Portico of Solomon) was one of the most impressive architectural features of the Second Temple complex in Jerusalem. Located along the eastern edge of the Temple Mount overlooking the Kidron Valley, this covered colonnade consisted of a double row of magnificent columns supporting a roof that provided shelter from sun and rain.

According to the Jewish historian Josephus, the colonnade was attributed to King Solomon and was believed to incorporate stones from the original Temple construction. Whether or not this tradition is historically accurate, the association with Solomon gave this portico special significance as a place of wisdom and teaching.

In the Gospels, Jesus is recorded teaching in Solomon's Porch during the Feast of Dedication (Hanukkah). When the Jews gathered around Him and asked if He was the Christ, Jesus responded with His famous 'I and my Father are one' declaration, which nearly resulted in His stoning (John 10:22-39).

After the resurrection and Pentecost, Solomon's Porch became the primary gathering place of the early Church. Acts 3:11 records that after Peter healed the lame man at the Beautiful Gate, 'all the people ran together unto them in the porch that is called Solomon's, greatly wondering.' There Peter delivered his second major sermon, quoting Deuteronomy 18:15-19 and identifying Jesus as 'that Prophet' whom Moses foretold. He also connected Jesus to the Abrahamic covenant, declaring that in Jesus 'shall all the kindreds of the earth be blessed' (Acts 3:25).

Acts 5:12 states that 'by the hands of the apostles were many signs and wonders wrought among the people; and they were all with one accord in Solomon's porch.' This continued gathering in the Temple precincts demonstrated the early Church's understanding of itself as the fulfillment of Judaism rather than a separate religion.

Solomon's Porch was destroyed along with the rest of the Temple by Roman forces in 70 CE. The current Al-Aqsa Mosque complex occupies the general area, though the exact location of Solomon's Porch is debated among scholars.

keyThemes.theme: Jesus as the Prophet like Moses
keyThemes.quotation: For Moses truly said unto the fathers, A prophet shall the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me; him shall ye hear in all things whatsoever he shall say unto you.
Ye are the children of the prophets, and of the covenant which God made with our fathers, saying unto Abraham, And in thy seed shall all the kindreds of the earth be blessed.
